## Formulas

For a given characteristics curve:

\begin{align*}
	V_{CE(sat)}    & = V_{CC}                                               \\
	I_{C(sat)}     & = \frac{V_{CC}}{R_C}                                   \\
	I_{\text{BQ}}  & = \frac{V_{\text{BB}}  - 0.7 \text{V}}{R{\text{B}}}    \\
	I_{\text{CQ}}  & = \beta_{\text{DC}} I_{\text{BQ}}                      \\
	V_{\text{CEQ}} & = V_{\text{CC}} - ( V_{R_C} = I_{\text{CQ}} R_{\text{C}} ) \\
\end{align*}

Note: The $_Q$ means that these values are present at the Q-point

Biasing of a transistor:

- If an amplifier is not biased with correct dc voltages on the input and output, it can go into saturation or cutoff when an input signal is applied.

> In a typical BJT npn transistor( I might be wrong here. DC voltage bias is applied as in a normal circuit. Then an input signal usually the ac voltage, is applied):
>
> - The input is the V_CC and output is the ground
> - Applying voltage to the ground means, making sure that the output voltage is lower than the input voltage
> - The input signal is the AC voltage applied at the base

> Taking $V_D$ as base–emitter diode turn-on voltage

>| V_BE   | State      |   |
>|--------|------------|---|
>| \< V_D | Cut-off    |   |
>| > V_D  | Linear     |   |
>|        | Saturation |   |

#### DC Load line

- Determined by the external circuit (VCC and RC), not the transistor itself,

$$V_{\rm CC}-V_{R_{\rm C}}-V_{\rm CE}=0$$

\begin{align*}
I_{C}
&= \frac{V_{CC} - V_{CE}}{R_{C}} \\
&= \frac{V_{CC}}{R_{C}} - \frac{V_{CE}}{R_{C}} \\
&= -\frac{V_{CE}}{R_{C}} + \frac{V_{CC}}{R_{C}} \\
\Aboxed{ I_C &= -\left( \frac{1}{R_{C}} \right) V_{CE} + \frac{V_{CC}}{R_{C}}}
\end{align*}

Equation of a straight line with a slope of $\frac{1}{R_{C}}$ , an x intercept of VCE = VCC, and a y intercept of VCC /RC, which is IC (sat).

#### **DC Load line:**

- The region along the load line including all points between saturation and cutoff is known as the linear region of the transistor's operation.
- Note: If the transistor is operated in this region, the output voltage is **ideally** a linear reproduction of the input.

![](_page_7_Figure_4.jpeg)

![](_page_7_Figure_5.jpeg)

#### Assume Beta=100

$$I_{\text{BQ}} = \frac{V_{\text{BB}} - 0.7 \text{ V}}{R_{\text{B}}} = \frac{3.7 \text{ V} - 0.7 \text{ V}}{10 \text{ k}\Omega} = 300 \text{ }\mu\text{A}$$
 
$$I_{\text{CQ}} = \beta_{\text{DC}} I_{\text{BQ}} = (100)(300 \text{ }\mu\text{A}) = 30 \text{ mA}$$
 
$$V_{\text{CEQ}} = V_{\text{CC}} - I_{\text{CQ}} R_{\text{C}} = 10 \text{ V} - (30 \text{ mA})(220 \Omega) = 3.4 \text{ V}$$
